journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Effect of different acid solutions on glass/epoxy composites

article-meta.aff: 1CEMUC, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal
2Department of Electromechanical Engineering, University of Beira Interior, Covilhã, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: PNB Reis, Department of Electromechanical Engineering, University of Beira Interior, Calçada Fonte do Lameiro, Edifício I das Engenharias, 6201-001 Covilhã, Portugal. Email: preis@ubi.pt

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Composite materials are exposed to a range of hostile environments with consequent degradation in terms of mechanical properties. However, the bibliography is not sufficient to establish a full knowledge about the effect of hostile environments on mechanical properties. This work intends to study the response to flexural and to low velocity impact of a glass fibre/epoxy composite after immersion in two different acid solutions, hydrochloric acid and sulphuric acid. These solutions affect significantly the flexural and impact strength, however, the hydrochloric acid was responsible for the worst results. The maximum load and elastic energy decreases with the impacts. On the other hand, the maximum displacement and damaged area showed an inverse tendency.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The interest in composite materials for hostile environments, as an alternative to stainless or coated steel ones, is becoming common. This interest is a consequence of their high specific strength and stiffness, competitive cost, good static and dynamic properties, good resistance to corrosion and simplified fabrication. For example, composite pipes are largely used in the chemical industry, building and infrastructures.1 However, GRP tanks and pipes may be degraded due to abrasion, change in brittleness or hardness, delamination or separation of fibre from matrix and degradation of matrix due to high speed flow of hard particles, cyclic loading and unloading of tanks, diffusion of acid solutions etc.2

The effect of hostile solutions on the GRP mechanical properties can be found in open literature. Mahmoud et al.3 showed that changes in the flexural strength, hardness and Charpy impact resistance depends upon the type of acids and the period of immersion. Banna et al.2 studied the effects of two aqueous acid solutions on different resins and concluded that the resins present different mechanical behaviour under aggressive solutions. Stamenovic et al.1 studied the effect of alkaline and acid solutions, concluding that the alkaline solution decreases the tensile strength and this tendency increases with the pH value. Some studies were also performed on GRP under stress corrosion cracking conditions.4–9 Stress-corrosion cracking in GRP occurs as a result of a combination between load and the corrosive environment.9 Sharp cracks initiate and propagate through the material as a direct consequence of the weakening of the glass fibres. The strength of the fibre was dramatically reduced by the chemical attack in the crack tip.

However, the bibliography is not sufficient to establish a full knowledge about the effect of hostile environments on the mechanical properties. Therefore, the aim of this work is to study the flexural and low velocity impact response of a glass fibre/epoxy composite after immersion in two different acid solutions: hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sulphuric acid (H2SO4). Both acids are highly corrosive and strong mineral acids. The HCl is a monoprotic acid with a vast application in the chemical industry. On the other hand, sulfuric acid is a diprotic acid with several industrial applications, namely, mineral processing, fertilizer manufacturing, oil refining, wastewater processing and chemical synthesis.

The bending test was selected because, according to Banna et al.,2 it is the most sensitive to the change of exposure conditions. On the other hand, impact damage is considered the primary cause of in-service delamination in composites. In fact, delaminations are very dangerous because they have severe effects on the performance of those materials10–15 and are of difficult visual detection.16,17 Moreover, low velocity impacts associated with highly corrosive environments have not been reported yet in bibliography.

sec.title: Material and experimental procedure
sec.p: Composite laminates were prepared in the laboratory from glass fibre Prepreg TEXIPREG® ET443 (EE190 ET443 Glass Fabric PREPREG from SEAL, Legnano, Italy) and processed in agreement with the manufacturer recommendations, using the autoclave/vacuum-bag moulding process. The laminates were manufactured with the stacking sequence [452, 902, −452, 02]s. The volume fraction of E-glass fibre is 44.5% and the laminates were processed using the autoclave/vacuum-bag moulding process. The processing setup consisted of several steps: make the hermetic bag and apply 0.05 MPa vacuum; heat up to 125℃ at a 3–5℃/min rate; apply a pressure of 0.5 MPa when a temperature of 120–125℃ is reached; maintaining pressure and temperature for 60 min; cool down to room temperature maintaining pressure and finally get the part out from the mould. The plates were manufactured in a useful size of 300 × 300 × 2.1 (mm3).

All the specimens used in the experiments were cut from those thin plates, using a diamond saw and a moving speed chosen to reduce the heat in the specimen. Figure 1(a) shows the dimensions of the specimens used in the static three-point bending (3PB) tests, while Figure 1(b) shows a schematic view of the three-point bending apparatus. Impact tests were performed using square specimens with 100 × 100 × 2.1 mm3. Before the exposure to corrosive environment, the impact samples were subjected to an impact of 8 J using an impactor with diameter of 10 mm and mass of 3.4 kg. Figure 1.
(a) Specimens geometry (dimensions in mm); (b) schematic view of the three-point bending apparatus.

The specimens were completely submerged into HCl and H2SO4. Both solutions have a concentration of 10% in weight (wt%) and a pH level of 1.5.18 The temperature of exposure was 25℃ (room temperature) and the exposure durations were 12, 24 and 36 days. It is important to note that both faces of the composites were exposed to acid environments, however, in real conditions only one face of composite structures is exposed. After exposition, the samples were washed with clean water and dried at room temperature.

The bending tests were performed according to ASTM D790-2, using a Shimadzu AG-10 universal testing machine equipped with a 5 kN load cell and TRAPEZIUM software at a displacement rate of 5 mm/min. All 3PB tests were also carried out at room temperature and for each condition five specimens were used.

The bending strength was calculated as the nominal stress at middle span section obtained using maximum value of the load and the nominal bending stress was calculated using: (1)σ=3P L2b h2 where P is the load, L the span length, b is the width and h the thickness of the specimen. The elastic stiffness modulus was calculated using the following linear elastic bending beams theory relationship: (2)E=ΔP·L348Δu·I where I is the moment of inertia of the cross-section, ΔP and Δu are, respectively, the load range and flexural displacement range at the middle span of the specimen. In equation (2), ΔP and Δu are defined from the linear region of the load-displacement curve. The elastic stiffness modulus was obtained from a linear regression of the load-displacement curve, considering the interval in the linear range with a correlation factor greater than 95%.

Low velocity impact tests were carried out using a drop weight-testing machine Instron-Ceast 9340. An impactor with a diameter of 10 mm and mass of 3.4 kg is used. The tests were performed on circular section samples of 70 mm and the impactor stroke at the centre of the samples obtained by centrally supporting the 100 × 100 mm specimens. The impact energy used for the first impact was 8 J, which corresponds to an impact velocity of 2.16 ms−1. All the other multi-impacts were performed using impact energy of 4 J, which corresponds to an impact velocity of 1.53 ms−1. For each condition, five specimens were tested at room temperature. After impact tests, all the specimens were inspected in order to evaluate the size and shape of the delaminations. As the glass-laminated plates are translucent, it is possible to obtain the image of the damage using photography. To achieve the best possible definition of the damaged area, the plates were photographed in counter-light using a powerful light source. Plates were framed in a window so that all the light could fall upon them.

The solvents absorption was obtained in accordance with BS EN ISO 62:1999. The samples were placed in an oven at 40℃ for 6 h, then cooled and weighed in order to obtain the dry weight (DW). Afterwards, a series of samples were immersed in the respective solutions (HCl and H2SO4) and periodically weighed to obtain the current wet weight (CWW). The solution absorption is defined in weight percentage (W%) using the following equation: (3)W%=CWW-DWDWx100

sec.title: Bending loads
sec.p:
As mentioned before, the material degradation, in terms of static properties, was analysed by bending tests. Figure 2 shows a representative example of the load versus flexural displacement curves for control samples and specimens exposed at HCl and H2SO4 solutions during 36 days. These curves are also representative of the other specimens that were immersed during 12 and 24 days. Both curves show a nearly linear elastic behaviour until 80 N and, after this value, a non-linear regime. After the peak, the load decreases with a similar behaviour in all curves. This phenomenon reveals that the damage mechanisms are very close. A typical picture of the failure mechanism is presented in Figure 3, where the damage observed for the control samples is representative of the other specimens that were immersed in acid solutions. For all laminates, all solutions and all time of immersion studied, the main damage observed occurs by the fibres fracture in the tensile surface followed by delaminations between the layers. These delaminations, independently of the solution, increases with the time of immersion. Figure 2.
Typical load-displacement curves for control samples, HCl and H2SO4 samples immersed during 36 days. H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.
Figure 3.
Typical failure mechanisms for control samples.

Five specimens were tested, for each condition, and the average values with the respective standard deviations are presented in Table 1. The bending strength is calculated as the maximum bending stress at middle span with the maximum loading obtained from the load-displacement plots equation (1) and the bending stiffness modulus is calculated using equation (2). Independently of the type of solution, it is possible to observe a significant decrease of the flexural strength and flexural modulus. However, to longer periods, the HCl is responsible by the lowest values. After 36 days of exposition, the flexural strength, for example, decreases around 16.2% for the HCl while this value is only about 11.6% for the H2SO4. Similar tendency was observed for the flexural modulus with values around 22.4% and 17.6%, respectively. These results indicate that the HCl is responsible for higher decrease of the flexural strength and modulus than the H2SO4, which is in agreement with the literature.18 Table 1.
Effect of corrosive environment on bending properties.
Samples Aver. flexural stress (MPa) Std Dev (MPa) Aver. flexural modulus (GPa) Std Dev (GPa)
Control samples 416.0 2.84 20.5 1.75
H2SO4 12 days 398.4 3.77 19.6 1.92
24 days 389.0 5.03 18.4 3.05
36 days 367.6 6.94 16.9 4.31
HCl 12 days 403.9 6.01 18.1 2.74
24 days 378.0 7.14 16.9 5.01
36 days 348.6 8.11 15.9 6.77
H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.

In order to explain the mechanical properties presented on Table 1, some complementary tests were done. The absorption curves for the H2SO4 and HCl were obtained and the results are presented in Figure 4. After 36 days (864 h) of exposure, both curves present a weight gain, with values relatively close, and the same trend is expected after this period of immersion. Therefore, it is possible to infer that this absorption leads to matrix expansion with the consequent occurrence of pits19 and/or to the development of microstresses in the composites.20,21 Figure 4.
Weight gain versus exposure duration.

The surface morphology was evaluated by scanning electron microscope (SEM), using Philips XL30 equipment. All specimens were sputter coated with a 10-nm layer of gold prior to SEM observation. Figure 5 shows the pictures that were obtained, where it is possible to observe that the unexposed samples (control samples) are characterized by a smooth surface (Figure 5(a)). On the other hand, the contact with the acid solutions promotes micro-cracks, which increase with the exposure time. Comparing Figure 5(d) and (g), it is possible to conclude that major damages occur on the samples exposed to the HCl. For Hammami and Al-Ghuilani,19 the combined action of water and corrosive fluids leads to the matrix expansion and to the occurrence of pits. After longer immersion periods, some blisters will appear and they start to grow by swelling (pressure) until final collapse.19 Figure 5.
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) pictures for: (a) Control samples, (b) Samples exposed to H2SO4 during 12 days; (c) Samples exposed to H2SO4 during 24 days; (d) Samples exposed to H2SO4 during 36 days; (e) Samples exposed to HCl during 12 days; (f) Samples exposed to HCl during 24 days; (g) Samples exposed to HCl during 36 days. H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.

The presence of micro-cracks was analyzed by means of roughness profiles, which were obtained by a Mitutoyo equipment, model SJ-500. Table 2 presents the statistic of the roughness measurements where is evident the effect of the solutions and exposure time on the surface topology. For example, in terms of the RZ parameter (average peak to valley height), it is possible to observe that the roughness increases with the exposure time, from 4.1280 to 5.3885 µm for the HCl solution and from 4.1436 to 5.2093 µm for the H2SO4 solution, but, after 36 days of exposure, the RZ value is slightly higher for HCl. Table 2.
Statistics of the roughness measurements.

Reduced valley depth, Rvk − 0.2270 ± 0.0712 1.3587 ± 0.0593 2.2339 ± 0.0502
H2SO4
Arithmetic average, Ra − 0.9188 ± 0.0289 1.0046 ± 0.0179 1.2197 ± 0.0496
Root mean square, Rq − 1.1091 ± 0.0706 1.2818 ± 0.0517 1.3798 ± 0.0696
Average peak to valley height, Rz − 4.1436 ± 0.0684 4.1687 ± 0.0566 5.2093 ± 0.0709
Evaluation length, Lo − 2.5032 ± 0.0008 2.5042 ± 0.0008 2.5045 ± 0.0008
Core roughness depth, Rk − 3.009 ± 0.0498 3.3 213 ± 0.0491 3.4064 ± 0.0398
Reduced peak height, Rpk − 1.413 ± 0.0113 1.7926 ± 0.0103 1.9008 ± 0.0201
Reduced valley depth, Rvk − 0.3847 ± 0.0873 1.1198 ± 0.0791 1.9938 ± 0.0573

Finally, the hardness was evaluated by ultramicroindentation using the Fisherscope H100 equipment and a load of 500 mN. Figure 6 shows the schematic representation of the typical load–penetration depth curves for the control samples and for laminates exposed to HCl and H2SO4 solutions during 36 days. Table 3 shows the average values of hardness, indentation modulus (ER) and Young’s modulus of the matrix. In order to account the geometric imperfections of the Vickers indenter, the thermal drift of the equipment and the uncertainty in the zero position, the hardness values were corrected according to Ref 22. The hardness, H, is defined as the maximum applied load during the indentation test, Pmax, divided by the contact area of the indentation immediately before unloading, AC. Comparing the results presented in Table 3, it is possible to conclude that the measured hardness of the polymeric matrix increases after immersion relatively to the control samples (≈0.26 GPa). The ER and the Young’s modulus of the matrix were obtained according the work presented by Antunes et al.,22 where the ER is a function of the Young’s modulus (E) and the Poisson ratio (ν) of the specimen and the indenter. For both solutions, these values (ER and E) are smaller when compared with those obtained for control samples. The decrease of Young’s modulus promoted by the corrosive solutions, and exposure time, can be associated to the lower flexural properties. Figure 6.
Schematic representation of the typical load–penetration depth curves. H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.
Table 3.
Effect of acid environment on average values of hardness, indentation modulus and Young’s modulus of the polymeric matrix.
Samples Aver. hardness VH (GPa) Std Dev (GPa) Aver ER (MPa) Std Dev (MPa) Aver. E (GPa) Std Dev (GPa)
Control samples
0.26 0.03 13.12 0.94 11.64 0.91
H2SO4 12 days 0.35 0.09 9.37 0.75 8.27 0.62
24 days 0.33 0.02 8.53 0.93 7.57 0.81
36 days 0.29 0.03 7.85 0.64 7 0.57
HCl 12 days 0.27 0.01 7.6 0.2 6.73 0.15
24 days 0.25 0.01 7.43 0.21 6.53 0.14
36 days 0.26 0.04 7.1 0.57 6.25 0.49

All this analysis agrees with the bibliography and it explains the decrease observed on mechanical properties when the laminates are exposed to the aggressive solutions. Mahmoud et al.3 showed that the drop of mechanical properties can be explained by the absorption, the penetration and the reaction that occur between the solutions and the composite constituents (matrix and fibres). In terms of matrix, the solution penetrates through the resin and separates out in micro-cracks.9 On the other hand, the degradation of the fibre/matrix interface is caused by the dehydration of the matrix and the penetration of solutions through the micro-cracks,1,23 crazes or similar voids in the matrix.9 However, for Stamenovic et al.,1 the most significant influence is verified in terms of fibre-matrix connection and consequent weakness of the load-carrying capacity of the laminate.

sec.title: Impact loads
sec.p: Low velocity impact events are very dangerous, because they are not easily detected visually and they can affect significantly the residual properties.10–17 In this context, this work intends to analyse the effect of acid environments on the residual life of laminates subjected to multi-impacts, after a first impact with higher energy. For this purpose, the laminates were pre-impacted with energy of 8 J, followed by multi-impacts of 4 J.

Figure 7 shows the typical load-time, load-displacement and energy-time curves for the first impact carried out with energy of 8 J. These typical diagrams are in agreement with those reported on the literature.24–27 The load-time and load-displacement curves are characterized by an increasing of the load up to a maximum value, Pmax, followed by a drop after the peak load. In terms of average values, the maximum load (Pmax), the maximum displacement and the impact time are, respectively, around 2798 N (St. Dev. ≈ 49 N), 4.73 mm (St. Dev. ≈ 0.1 mm) and 8.42 ms (St. Dev. ≈ 0.2 ms). For the curves that represent the evolution of the energy with time, the beginning of the plateau of the curve coincides with the loss of contact between the striker and the specimen. The elastic energy can be calculated as the difference between the absorbed energy and the energy at peak load,27 which is around 22.5% (St. Dev. ≈ 1.54 %). Finally, Figure 8 shows typical damages occurred on laminates after impact loads, where the delamination shape is oriented in the fibres direction of the adjacent lower ply (45°) and the crack is also aligned with the fibres direction of this lowest ply. Some matrix cracking induced by shear can also be identified in the middle group of layers (90°/−45°), which demonstrates an interaction phenomenon between matrix cracking and delamination, thus constituting a complex damage mechanism. More details about the damages promoted by impact loads can be found in Ref 28. Figure 7.
Typical load-time, load-displacement and energy-time curves for laminates impacted at 8 J.
Figure 8.
Typical picture of the damaged laminates impacted at 8 J.

These pre-impacted laminates after immersion in HCl and H2SO4 solutions were subjected to impact energy of 4 J. The curves obtained are similar to those presented in Figure 7, but with different average values, as shown in Table 4. For example, comparing the control samples with specimens that were immersed in the H2SO4 solution during 12 days, it is possible to conclude that the maximum load decreases around 6.3% while the displacement increase is about 13.4%. On the other hand, comparing the values obtained between the control samples and the specimens immersed in the HCl solution during 12 days, it is possible to observe a decrease of the load capacity around 5.4% while the displacement increases about 5.1%. The exposure time present a considerable effect. Comparing the maximum load values obtained between 12 days and 36 days of exposition, for example, a decrease around 14.3% for the H2SO4 and 8.2% for the HCl can be found. In terms of maximum displacement an increase around 9.9% and 10.6% was observed, respectively. Table 4.
Effect of corrosive environment and exposure time on laminates pre-impacted.
Samples Aver. maximum load (N) Std Dev (N) Aver. maximum displacement (mm) Std. Dev (mm) Aver. contact time (ms) Std Dev. (ms)
Control samples 2721.4 64.0 3.13 0.13 5.57 0.21
H2SO4 12 days 2550.6 37.9 3.55 0.27 6.67 0.22
24 days 2297.6 53.1 3.63 0.19 6.85 0.27
36 days 2186.9 44.3 3.9 0.18 6.96 0.19
HCl 12 days 2573.7 45.1 3.29 0.14 6.57 0.19
24 days 2439.2 68.7 3.39 0.17 6.79 0.26
36 days 2362.6 60.3 3.64 0.12 7.0 0.13

Figure 9 shows the effect of acid solutions and the exposure time on the elastic energy and damaged area, for the first impact at 4 J. The elastic energy was calculated as the difference between the absorbed energy and the energy at peak load.27 It is possible to observe that the elastic energy decreases when the samples are exposed to corrosive environments and, this tendency, shows to be highly dependent with the exposition time. For example, when the exposition time between 12 and 36 days is compared, a decrease of 12.6% for the HCl solution and 13.7% for the H2SO4 solution occurs. As expected, the damaged area increases with the decreasing of elastic energy. Comparing with the control samples, the laminates immersed in HCl and H2SO4 solutions during 36 days present an increasing of the damaged areas around 20.8% and 18.8%, respectively. This tendency agrees with the flexural properties studied in the last section, where the major damages occur for samples exposed to the HCl. Figure 9.
Effect of the aggressive solutions on elastic energy and damage area after first impact at 4 J.

According to David-West et al.,29 the impact bending stiffness has been known as an important property to assess the damage resistance of a composite. The slope of the ascending section of the load-displacement plot is the bending stiffness, however, more details to determine this property can be found in Ref 29. Table 5 presents the impact bending stiffness, for the first impact at 4 J, showing the effect of the corrosive environment and exposure time on the damage resistance. For both solutions, it is possible to observe that the impact bending stiffness decreases relatively to the value obtained for the control samples. The impact bending stiffness is also highly dependent of exposure time, according to the values presented in Table 5. Therefore, this analysis confirms the tendency observed in Figure 9, where the damaged area increases with the presence of the acid solutions and time exposure. Table 5.
Impact bending stiffness after first impact at 4 J.
Sample Impact bending stiffness (N/mm) Std Dev (N/mm) Variation relatively to control samples (%)
Control 1435.7 48.9
H2SO4 12 days 1280.6 38.1 −10.8
24 days 847.6 44.7 −40.9
36 days 630.9 49.3 −56.1
HCl 12 days 1125.7 54.7 −21.6
24 days 792.6 61.1 −44.8
36 days 684.1 63.4 −52.4
H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.

The effect of multi impacts was studied and Table 6 shows the impact resistance for both acid solutions. The laminates were considered failed when perforation occurs. The perforation is defined when the impactor completely moves through the samples. It is possible to observe that the resistance of the laminates to the repeated low velocity impacts is very dependent on the corrosive environment and exposure time. Figure 10 shows the evolution of the maximum load with the number of impacts, where it is possible to observe that the average load decreases with the increase of impact numbers. For both solutions, the exposure time promotes a significant decrease of the average load. However, the contact time between impactor and specimen increases, as shown in Figure 11. Solutions and exposure time are responsible by the higher contact time relative to the control samples. A similar tendency can be observed for the maximum displacement, as shown in Figure 12. This behaviour is explained by the specimen bending stiffness, which decreases with the increase of the impact numbers. In fact, plate deflection is proportional to the bending stiffness. Figure 10.
Evolution of the maximum load with the impact numbers for: (a) Samples exposed to HCl; (b) Samples exposed to H2SO4. H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.
Figure 11.
Evolution of the contact time with the impact numbers for: (a) Samples exposed to HCl; (b) Samples exposed to H2SO4.
Figure 12.
Evolution of the displacement with the impact numbers for: (a) Samples exposed to HCl; (b) Samples exposed to H2SO4. H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.
Table 6.
Impact resistance.
Sample Number of impacts to failure
Control 14
H2SO4 12 days 9
24 days 9
36 days 8
HCl 12 days 10
24 days 9
36 days 9
H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.

Finally, Figure 13 presents the evolution of the elastic energy with the number of impacts. As expected, the elastic energy decreases when the number of impacts increases. This tendency shows to be very dependent on the solution type and exposure time. Lower elastic energy means that the damage area is major and this relationship can be observed in Figure 14. From this figure, it is evident that there is an increase in the damaged area with the number of impacts and, this tendency, is inverse for the impact bending stiffness. In terms of impact bending stiffness, the results agree with those reported by David-West et al.29 and they prove to be an important property to assess the damage resistance of composites. Figure 13.
Evolution of the elastic energy with the impact numbers for: (a) Samples exposed to HCl; (b) Samples exposed to H2SO4. H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.
Figure 14.
Evolution of the damage area and impact bending stiffness with the impact numbers for: (a) Samples exposed to HCl; (b) Samples exposed to H2SO4. H2SO4: sulphuric acid; HCl: hydrochloric acid.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This work studied the flexural and low velocity impact response of a glass fibre/epoxy composite after immersion in HCl and H2SO4. It was shown that the flexural strength and flexural modulus are affected significantly by the acid solutions. Moreover, the exposure time shows to be determinant on the flexural properties. However, the hydrochloric acid is responsible for the lowest flexural properties

The impact strength is very dependent of the acid environment and exposure time. One more time the hydrochloric acid is responsible for the lowest impact resistance. The maximum load decreases with the number of impacts, however, the maximum displacement presents an inverse tendency. The elastic energy decreases also with the number of impacts and, consequently, the damaged area increases.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
